Question: wat is a good sceince fair project idea?
Answer: I won  the Regional Championship for this one and a trip to Canada, it was called Copy Cat. What you do is take cards with different color combinations on them and show them to students ranging from kinder-garden to the 12th asking them which color combination is their favorite. The first case is where you do it individually and then as a collective class. You should find that the younger children will stand by their first choices even during a group decision. As the children get older they are more prone to follow the choices of their peers until the later years where individuality take hold once again and they start to diversify. I used pie charts and percentages to display alot of the information and also split up the classes into males and females for a follow up experiment. Its been many many years since I did it but I'm sure the results will fascinate the judges. Good Luck!

Title: Modern Human Evolution?  How did all populations of humans advance at the same time?
Question: For approximately 150-200,000 years, humans essentially lived like very smart animals, then fairly suddenly, about 10,000 years ago, we all seemed to have discovered agriculture and "civilization"..a few thousand years later we were all writing.  I have never seen a decent, logical explanation for how all the populations of the Earth took this "great leap forward" at the same time-After 150-200,000 years, suddenly within about 1% of that time frame, there are cities everywhere from the Middle East, to China, to North and South America?  Writing starting independently everywhere?  For me, this is the most mysterious event in all of history-any ideas?
Answer: Hey! Your "other" question is already cluttered up with some high voltage discussion and nice arguements so, I thought I should post my answer here as it is more peaceful and calm here. I was wondering whether I should have posted my answer there? 

Now, I'll try to make sense while talking about a topic that I know little about. 

1- It all started with the arrival of the first bipedal- Australopithecus anamensis. (some might argue that it was Ardipithecus ramidus). Ok, the point is, as our ancestors started to learn to walk on two feet, they had some challenges to face as bipedalism reduced their speed considerably putting them at a clear disadvantage against their predators.
Now, as this problem was faced by all the hominids all over the world at the same time, it led to some parallel thoughts (and thus inventions and discoveries) all over the world e.g. building homes, making weapons and tools etc. (The stone tools were first made by the handy man i.e. Homo habilis and not Australopithecus).
This tool technology was spread by Homo ergaster as they  migrated outside Africa.

2- Then, in the course of evolution, the early humans started to have a complex cultural lives and they grew emotionally, e.g. the Neanderthals (who aren't our direct ancestors) started to bury the dead.

3- As the homo species like homo erectus, homo neanderthalis, homo heidelbergenesis and ancient homo sapiens (Cro Magnon) made further advances in creativity and productivity, they all felt a natural need to pen down their thoughts. This led to the cave painitngs and carvings. All of those paintings can be interpreted as diary entries as you may see that the paintings and carvings simply depict what the early men "did" i.e. hunting, using tools etc.
So, I guess it is understandable why the "pictorial-scripts" developed contemporarily to each other.

4- But the question still remains: Why were the origin of world's ancient scripts so contemporary to each other? I guess, as man found the pictorial depiction of thoughts and emotions more and more unconvenient and tedious due to the diverseness of thoughts and situations to be depicted, it started taking help of symbols. Perhaps, this behaviour was so "human-like" that every sub-species of the homo sapiens followed this pattern of 'depicting thoughts symbolically' universally.

5- Another reason of this might be migration. Before the ancient civilizations like Inka, Mesopotamia, Egyptian etc. even came into existence, the early hominids led a nomadic life. According to the "Out of Africa Hypothesis", all the modern humans "Homo Sapiens" originated from Africa. Later, they migrated to Africa, Asia and Europe and formed groups.
So, I guess due to their similar ancestral origins, the human beings had a common problem solving approach and hence, attempted the problem of inconvenience of pictorial scripts in a nearly identical manner.

The scientific difference in the scripts can explain that they were devised on completely different grounds but, the approach was similar due to common origins and creative grounds.

Title: Why does ur body itch after u exercise for the first time in a long time?
Question: I jogged a mile yesterday for the first time in 2 years and my legs itched like they were on fire!

1.Your feet and legs were absorbing impact energy from the act of running. This is no different from hitting the palm of your hand against the table top over and over again. The atoms in your hand swell from the absorbed energy and then once you stop hitting the table, slowly release that energy in an attempt to get back to their normal existing ground state. the transferring or processing of that absorbed energy will feel like itching which is really just a lesser degree of pain.

2.Your legs were also releasing stored energy throughout your leg muscles during your run, adding to the absorbed energy from running. 

This is also why a sunburn will itch like crazy, absorbed solar energy is finding a way out of your body.

As your body cools down the itching may get worse, because cooling will close your pores, trapping the heat.

Title: HELP! i have a scratchy throat, my nose is stuffy and it has been this way for about three months?
Question: I have had a stuffy nose for about three months. i have been to the doctor butthe antibiotic medicine I was prescribed didn't clear my sinus.\nI dont have any health insurance so I can not go to a allegry doctor because I can't afford it.\nI need suggestions as to what I can do to help my sinuses and scratchy throat or  adoctor I can see forlow payments
Answer: You might just have allergies, but I'm sure the doctor must have considered that and told you to try Benadryl, Claritin, or Allegra at some point.\n\nAntibiotics are appropriate if you have a bacterial sinusitis.  The particular bacteria might be resistant to whatever antibiotics they gave you.  You would need a culture of your snot to determine this.\n\nUltimately though, the problem probably started with poor sinus drainage.  Even with appropriate antibiotics, the problem will recur if the sinus drainage issue isn't resolved.  In the short term, Sudafed would probably help.  I don't like the idea of using Sudafed for more than a couple of weeks though.  If you have allergies exacerbating the situation (do you have a history of seasonal allergies, or any new pets?), then Benadryl or non-sedating Claritin would help.  For really bad cases, I know of a doctor that swears by the Neti pot (he uses it himself).  It's like a little watering pot for plants.  You fill it up with water or saline and pour it into your nose.  Basically you're physically cleaning out your sinus openings.\n\nIf there is a possibility you're allergic to something, I would try Claritin and the Neti pot first for 3 days and see if the symptoms improve.  If you don't think it's an allergy, try Sudafed + Neti pot.  If that doesn't do it, I would go back to the doctor and try another antibiotic together with the Sudafed + Neti pot.  VERY IMPORTANT: IF THE INFECTION SPREADS--YOUR CHEEK BECOMES RED AND PAINFUL OR IT HURTS TO MOVE AN EYE--GO STRAIGHT TO THE ER.  Sinusitis is normally just an inconvenience, not a serious health problem.  It can sometimes spread, however, and cause cellulitis in your cheek or an orbital abscess in your eye socket--both very serious conditions.

Title: What will make me seem and be more responsible to my parents?
Question: I am 13 and I am really responsible. I want to get a job when I turn 14 (thats the legal working age here). My mom doesn't think I am responsible and she keeps saying stuff infront of my dad  like the only reason I want to get a job is to meat guys. Wich is not true, I am not even interested in guys right now believe it or not. I have  never had a boy friend or been crazy about a guy or anything. Why is she trying to make me look so immature infront of my dad? He is already saying that he doesn't like the idea. I really need some tips!
Answer: The way to solve any problem is to look at it carefully, then come up with a plan...

So why does Mom think you're irresponsible? Do you do things like homework, and chores, without fuss or complaint? Does she have to ask you several times to do something? 

Have you been up to anything recently that she told you not to do?

If your track record here isn't great, it's time to lay a better foundation -- plan on a few months of being  a model citizen to prove yourself before approaching the topic again.

Okay, so if you've got that part - you do your homework, do your cchores promptly without whining, haven't been up to anything that got (or would get) you in trouble, then it's time to lay it out professionally.

You ask to meet with your parents. Before that, you write out:

> the reasons why you want to work ("I'd like to earn money for movies"  "It will look good on college applications and resumes late" whatever your reasons are)

> your plan for making sure the job doesn't interfere with school ("I'd only work during school breaks"  "I'll only work one day a week" whatever your plan is)

> anything that argues that you're responsible enough to handle it 

> what you could gain from working ("money for clothes"  "I'll put half of what I earn into savings for college" "experience working with other people" etc.)

Then you meet with them and give them a copy of all of this.

Understand that they still might say "no."  If so, ask them, calmly, why they're saying "no." Discuss it with them, calmly, but don't throw a tantrum - that will just prove that you're not mature enough.

If they do say "no," ask them to help you figure out another way to earn money. Good luck!

Title: What is advertismen? How do I get rid of it?
Question: I tried to remove by going to add and remove programs,restarted computer as it instructed and it is still listed in add and remove programs. Could this be why Chrysler Golf Challenge graphics are messed up?
Answer: Advertismen is a type of spyware that most anti-spyware programs don't pick up. I can give you directions on how to remove it, but they involve modifying your system registry. Please be very careful when altering your registry and don't modify anything except the file included in the instructions.
   1. Close ALL Internet Explorer, Firefox, etc. windows.
   2. Click on start, then click on "Run..." and type:   regedit and click "ok"
   3. On the left side click "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE" then SOFTWARE> Microsoft> Windows NT> CurrentVersion> Windows
   4. On the right-hand side you should see a String called “AppInit_DLLs” with a value of “pushow*.dll” where * is a random number.
   5. Right-click on this String and click Delete and then exit regedit.
   6. Go to "My Computer" and open "C:\windows\system32\"
   7. In that folder there is a file called "pushow*.dll," where * is the random number you saw above. Delete all pushow*.dll files.

That's all you need to do to remove the program. In the future, be careful about downloading things when you're not sure what they are. If you don't already have an anti-spyware program, I suggest you download adaware: http://www.lavasoft.de/software/adaware/

Question: what is cultural web of an organization? help!?
Answer: Cultural web is a management tool to assess the culture of an organisation especially before and after a change program.It comprises measurement of six dimensions of an organisation to determine its paradigm.. these six dimensions are

1. Symbols... physical symbols like style of workplace etc
2. Power structures... informal or formal power holders
3. Control systems...eg. rewards and punishments
4. Organisation...e.g hirarchical
5. Rituals and routines...common ways of doing things in the org.
6. Stories...what employees talk about.

Snapshot of cultural web before and after a change program can throw some light on the success of the program.

Title: Is there less gravity at the poles?
Question: centrifugal force?
Answer: No, in fact exactly the opposite.\n\nThe Earth is not exactly spherical but rather is a little bit like a "squashed" sphere, with the radius at the equator slightly larger than the radius at the poles (this shape can be explained by the effect of centripetal acceleration on the material that makes up the Earth, exactly as described above). This has the effect of slightly increasing your weight at the poles (since you are close to the centre of the Earth and the gravitational force depends on distance) and slightly decreasing it at the equator.\n\nAs far as centrifugal (actually centripital) force goes, it also serves to increase the effects of gravity at the poles.

Question: Would like a detail definition of a "Church Trustee"?
Answer: Church Trustees Job Description   

1. Become familiar with, and update as needed, the by-laws of the church and the 
policies being used by the Board of Trustees. 
2. Work collaboratively to set policies with a long-range perspective for church 
organizational units. 
3. Function as a communication link between the members of the congregation and the 
Board of Trustees. (Some possibilities include: telephoning congregants, organizing 
small group meetings, writing follow-up letters, and making announcements for Sunday 
Services). 
4. Attend scheduled Board of Trustee meetings (usually one a month is scheduled). 
5. Accept appointment to and participate in short-term board task groups. 
6. Attend and assist with town hall discussion meetings and Congregational decision 
meetings. 
7. Attend Board of Trustees Retreat (usually held in the spring after the Board of 
Trustees elections). 
8. Assist the Finance Council as necessary. 
9. Be aware of Unitarian Universalism in a larger context than Lincoln, such as the 
Prairie Star District and the Unitarian Universalist Association. 
10. Support the decisions of the Board of Trustees.

Answer: Because after milk is extracted, it is then cooled in the dairy and transported in refrigerated tankers for processing. Unchilled milk would soon go sour due to acid production by lactobacilli. Even if kept refrigerated, raw milk goes off rapidly due to the action of psychrophilic (cold-tolerant) bacteria. These produce proteinases and lipases which break down both the protein and the fat in milk, causing rancid and bitter tastes and clotting. \n\nOne unusual type of bacteria which can grow is called Alcaligenes viscolactis – this produces sticky threads of exopolysaccharide in the milk called ropiness.\n\n:)\nPeace

Question: Anybody know about how heat release from a power transformer ??
Answer: In addition to unwanted electrical effects, transformers may also exhibit undesirable physical effects, the most notable being the production of heat and noise. Noise is primarily a nuisance effect, but heat is a potentially serious problem because winding insulation will be damaged if allowed to overheat. Heating may be minimized by good design, ensuring that the core does not approach saturation levels, that eddy currents are minimized, and that the windings are not overloaded or operated too close to maximum ampacity. \n\nLarge power transformers have their core and windings submerged in an oil bath to transfer heat and muffle noise, and also to displace moisture which would otherwise compromise the integrity of the winding insulation. Heat-dissipating "radiator" tubes on the outside of the transformer case provide a convective oil flow path to transfer heat from the transformer's core to ambient air: \n\nFollow the link for more information.\nHope this helps you!

Title: Could you please answer this?
Question: when a voter is unable to vote outside of his/her work hours, what are the 3 obligations of an employer to his employees regarding voting?

( could u please answer is properly, because i need it for my civics assigment) thank you
Answer: Hope this helps

ALASKA

·  Time: Employees who do not have sufficient non-work time to vote (i.e., do not have at least two hours available either before or after work during which the polls are open) may take off time sufficient to enable them to vote.  

·  Pay: Time off must be with pay.

·  Penalty: Not Specified

ARIZONA

·  Time: Employees must be given up to three consecutive hours if they do not have at least three consecutive hours of non-working time at the beginning or end of the work day while the polls are open.  Employees must submit a request to be eligible for time off prior to election day. The employer may specify the hours to be used, although those hours must be consecutive.

·  Pay: Employers are required to pay normal wages for any time taken.

·  Penalty: An employer who does not comply with Arizona law is guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor and may be fined up to $750.

ARKANSAS

·  Time: The employer must schedule work hours so that each employee can vote.  

·  Pay: Not Specified 

·  Penalty: An employer that does not comply with Arkansas law is subject to a fine of between $25.00 and $250.00.

CALIFORNIA

·  Time: Employees must be given sufficient time off to enable them to vote at either the beginning or end of the shift, unless otherwise agreed upon by the employer and employee.  Employees must make an application for time off at least two work days before the election if they know or should have known that extra time would be needed.  Employers must post a conspicuous notice of any statewide election, along with a list of employee's rights and duties, at least ten days before the election.  

·  Pay: Employers are required to pay employees normal wages for the time off for up to two hours.

·  Penalty: An employer who does not comply with California law may be fined an amount not exceeding $1,000 or face imprisonment for sixteen months or two to three years.

COLORADO

·  Time: Employees must be allowed to be absent from work for up to two hours in order to vote unless the employee has three or more consecutive non-working hours during the polling period.  To be eligible for the time off an employee must make an application prior to the day of the election.  Employers may specify the hours for the absence.  At employee request, such hours must be either at the beginning or end of the shift.

·  Pay: The employer must pay absent employees their normal wages for the two hours.  

·  Penalty: Failure to comply with Colorado law may subject employers to fines up to $1,000 and/or jail for up to one year.  Any corporation that fails to comply may also forfeit its charter and right to do business in Colorado.

GEORGIA

·  Time: Employees must be allowed to take off up to two hours unless the employee has two hours of free (non-work) time while the polls are open.  To be eligible, the employee must give the employer reasonable notice of his/her need for the time off.  The employer may specify which hours the employee may be absent.

·  Pay: Not Specified

·  Penalty: Not Specified

HAWAII

·  Time: Employees must be allowed up to two consecutive hour's absence (not including lunch or rest periods) unless the employee has two consecutive non-working hours while the polls are open. Additionally, employees must be able to prove, via a voter's receipt that the time taken was actually used for voting. 

·  Pay: Employers must pay the employees normal wages for the period of absence, and they may not reschedule the employee's work time to bring it within the two-hour "free time" exception.  If the employee does not use the time granted to vote, the employer may make the appropriate deductions from the employee's salary or wages.  

·  Penalty: Failure to comply with Hawaii law may subject employers to a fine of between $50 and $300.

ILLINOIS

·  Time: Employees are allowed up to two hours off in order

Title: what is shuck n jive?
Question: what does this mean, exactly?
Answer: "To shuck and jive" originally referred to the intentionally misleading words and actions that African-Americans would employ in order to deceive racist Euro-Americans in power, both during the period of slavery and afterwards.  The expression was documented as being in wide usage in the 1920s, but may have originated much earlier.\n\n"Shucking and jiving" was a tactic of both survival and resistance.  A slave, for instance, could say eagerly, "Oh, yes, Master," and have no real intention to obey.  Or an African-American man could pretend to be working hard at a task he was ordered to do, but might put up this pretense only when under observation.  Both would be instances of "doin' the old shuck 'n jive."\n\nToday, the expression has expanded somewhat from earlier usage, and is now sometimes used to mean "talking pure baloney," "goofing off," or "goofing around."  The original meaning of deceit often remains, however.

Copper (II) sulfate, water and sulfur dioxide are produced when copper and sulfuric acid react together.

Cu + H2SO4 = CuSO4 + H2O + SO2 but then i don't know how to balance it.
Help please!!!!
Answer: First, notice you have two S atoms on right hand side.
To get two S atoms on left, you must have two H2SO4 molecules.
Your equation is now Cu + 2H2SO4 ---> CuSO4 + SO2 + ??
If you subtract right from left, you are left with 4H + 2O atoms, for 2H2O
So final eq is Cu + 2H2SO4 ---> CuSO4 + SO2 + 2H2O

Hope this helps you to approach these equation-balancing problems methodically.

Title: I'm inheriting a house in trust to my brother and I. He wants to keep it, I want to cash out. Capital gains?
Question: How can I sell my half to my brother without getting screwed, regarding capitol gains taxes? It's not my primary residence.\nIt's a $300,000 dollar property with $60,000 left on the mortgage. What would you do?
Answer: The mortgage is not relevant for taxes.  You need to know your tax basis in the property.  Normally, property received by inheritance is valued at the time of death to determine basis.  This means you should not have a capital gain.  You said the house is "in trust".  If this is true, neither you or your brother own the house, the trust does.  Your ability to "cash out" is determined by the terms of the trust and the decision of the trustee.  You need to consult and attorney who needs to read the trust documents.

Title: Can I take him to court for calling me a lesbian?
Question: I have a roommate who is  like a sister to me.  She and I have known each other since high school.  When I left my husband, hers left her around the same time.  For finacial reasons, and moral support, we moved in together with our daughters, who are about a year apart in age.

Recently, my friend's ex has decided (for custody issues) that she and I are a couple.  While I have many gay friends and have very short hair, I am in no way a lesbian.  He is planning on citing me in the custody case as a reason that his daughter should not be with her mother (There are many other issues, but this is the one that pertains to me specifically).

My question is: Can I take him to court for slandering my name?  and if not, how can I get this guy to stop?  My daughter and my roommate's daughter both hear this crap come from his mouth every weekend when he brings them back from their separate father-daughter weekends. And I'm sick of it.

Any suggestions?
Answer: There is one barrier that makes slander cases difficult. A 'well-known' attorney explained this to me a few years ago... you have to prove malicious intent.

As was explained to me, someone making false, negative statements about you isn't enough for a slander case. First there has to be harm done - there was in this case, there has to be some sort of loss - this could be as simple as loss of reputation and last, the offender must have been purposely trying to harm you (malicious intent).

Malicious intent is supposedly the hardest part to prove.

I would say that in your case, you would have a rather easy time proving malicious intent because the offender has a clear motivate to attempt to smear your reputation.

Btw, most attorneys require a large 'down payment' for slander cases... anywhere from 5 to 10k.

Title: how is caffeine extracted using chloroform?
Question: what are the different mehtods of extracting caffeine from tea? 
by using chloroform, how sure can i be that the results i collected are truely chloroform?
Answer: To separate caffeine, you could use HPLC, LC, GC, or TLC, which are all chromatography techniques. 

If you do a physical separation, a polar organic solvent would do nicely.

To make sure that you are actually extracting the chloroform, suspend the separatory funnel on a ring off of a ring stand. Wait 10 mins. You'll see two layers, a top layer and bottom layer.

Chloroform has a density of 1.48 g/mL and water has a density of 1 g/mL, so the chloroform will be the bottom layer. Use the sep funnel to recover all the chloroform. At the end, I'd run saturated sodium chloride through the chloroform and separate that, to clear any nonorganics from the chloroform.

After that, you can put the chloroform on a rotavap or do TLC to see if you have caffeine and caffeine only (doubtful)

Title: What are the dimensions (length, width, and height or thickness) of the physical universe (in light years)?
Question: Basically, how big is the universe?  If not actually known at this time, is the actual size of the entire universe considered to be knowable (i.e. that there is some possibility of measuring or estimating its size but the techniques are not currently available).

I've read that the universe is thought to be "saddle shaped"
and expanding at an accelerating rate.  If I correctly understand some research that I've done in Wickipedia, the rate of expansion of the universe is 70 (km/s)/Mps or 70 kilometers per second per megaparsec [i.e. million parsecs].

I don't understand parsecs, except that they are a measurement of distance similar to light years.  Also, I don't understand the megaparsec part of the expansion rate. What does it mean for example, to say that the universe is expanding at a rate of 70 kilometers per second per (x number of light years)?

One more thing, I was not able to find a rate of acceleration of expansion. Would the form be increase of distance of expansion/s/s?
Answer: "...What are the dimensions (length, width, and height or thickness) of the physical universe (in light years)?..."
The universe can't be measured in terms of length, width, and height. Such parameters require some reference point from which measurements can be made, along with some distant boundary where the measurement would end. You simply can't do that with the universe because the universe is isotropic, meaning it's the same in all directions from any observing point. From Earth we can look outward in any direction and 'see' about 13.7-billion light years. From Earth that represents a boundary. Here comes the tricky part: if some alien in a galaxy 13.7-billion light years away from Earth looked outward in all directions (including back towards Earth) they'd 'see' a universe that appeared to be 13.7-billion light years in scope. In other words, the universe has no boundary. To have one it would have to be inside some "thing" else, and there's absolutely no evidence that such is the case.

To confuse the issue even more, if we had the ultimate telescope with limitless viewing power we still will never be able to see into the universe beyond a certain range. That's because at almost the same instant of the Big Bang the universe briefly expanded faster than light (this doesn't violate relativity because it was the space of the universe that did the expanding). In our 'normal' universe the speed of light is the speed limit which prevents us from ever seeing any of that inflation because it's moving away faster than the speed of light.
-----------------------------------------------------------
"...I've read that the universe is thought to be "saddle shaped..."
More recent observations point more towards the universe being geometrically "flat." This simply means that the universe appears to be infinite, that its space will expand forever while cooling more and more over the eons.
------------------------------------------------------------
"...What does it mean for example, to say that the universe is expanding at a rate of 70 kilometers per second per (x number of light years)?..."
You've described the so-called Hubble Constant. (70 km/sec/Mpc) It means if galaxy 'A' is 1 Mpc (1-million ly) away from us it's recessional velocity will be 70 km/sec. If galaxy 'B' is 2 Mpc away then it's velocity will be 140 km/sec It's important to keep in mind though that it's space that's expanding like that, not the galaxies moving THROUGH space; they just get carried along.
------------------------------------------------------------
"...I was not able to find a rate of acceleration of expansion..."
I've been looking for a figure too. So far the only thing I've come up with is -3.15^36 /sec/sec  Darned if I know what the units of measurement are though. Maybe someone else on Yahoo can help us out with that.

Question: What's the shortest possible explanation of the offside rule?
Answer: If, when the ball is last touched by a teammate, is the player in question closer to the opponent's goal line than:
1) the half line?
2) the ball?
3) the second to the last opponent?

If you answer yes to all of these, then he was in an offside position when the ball was touched and you can ask the last question:
4) Did he gain an advantage from his position?

If you say yes to all questions, the player is guilty of an offside infraction.

However, you cannot be found guilty of an offside infraction if you receive the ball directly from a: goal-kick, throw-in, or corner kick.

Title: As a new eBay seller, How could I enhance my eBay feedback score in short time??
Question: My feedback score is (0).. I cant sell a thing..I dont have any feedback. people dont wanna buy from me because of my score. what should i do?
Answer: There are two ways to go about it:

1. Buy from other sellers. What I did when I started was to look for any $0.99 items or cheaper, bid on it to get my score up.

2. Review the way you sell your items. Many members realize that everyone starts from 0. In my other eBay account, I did not do #1 and instead proceeded to sell with 0 feedback. Buyers bought from me, no problem with 0 feedback. 

Check if your item actually fits well with ebay - one of the realities of ebay is NOT all items can be sold on ebay. Do a search for completed items to see if people are buying your type of products, and for what price.

Also check your actual listing. Check the photos, check the titles of your listings to make sure the keywords are there, check the description, check your shipping and handling policies, check your payment policies. And if everything else fails, try to lower your price to get some bidding nibble.

eBay has several ways for you to determine exactly what the hot items to sell on their marketplace: 

Items In Demand = the most popular items currently within that particular category. To see the In Demand page, go to http://pages.ebay.com/sellercentral/sellbycategory.html  

Hot Items by Category Report = a monthly report that lists the fastest growing categories on eBay for the previous month. Go to http://pages.ebay.com/sellercentral/whatshot.html and select "Hot Items by Category" from the menu on the left. 

eBay Pulse = "a daily snapshot of current trends, hot picks, and cool stuff on eBay". Go to http://pulse.ebay.com/ to see eBay Pulse in action. 

Merchandising Calendar = eBay promotes specific categories on its home page each month. Savvy eBayers know that this home page exposure results in more interest in such categories. Go to http://pages.ebay.com/sellercentral/calendar.html  to view the current Merchandising Calendar.

Title: When buying a home, why is the appraisal usually just above the loan amount rather than actual property value?
Question: We're purchasing our first home.  When I asked for a copy of the appraisal, our realtor indicated that the appraiser normally stopped just above the requested loan amount, even if the home would appraise higher.  Why is this?  If we want an actual appraisal, do we have to purchase that separately?  We're paying for the appraisal ourselves & would really like to know the true appraised value of the home we're buying.
Answer: Because normally the appraiser feels it is his job only to justify the price that the house is selling for.  Remember the appraiser is ultimately there to protect the bank that is loaning you the money for the home.  If you default they want to know that they will be able to recoup their costs.\n\nIf the appraiser said that the house was worth 50,000 more than you are paying for it are you going to now pay the seller 50,000 more?  If the appraiser says it is worth less than you are paying for it, then the bank is going to make you pay cash for the difference, the bank won't give you a mortgage for more than the appraisal.\n\nThere is no incentive for the appraiser to come in with a high appraisal.  They only need to appraise it for the amount that the current transaction is.\n\nThe buyer and seller have agreed on a price, the appraisal is there to give peace of mind that the house is worth at least that much.

Answer:

Question: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using a kidney machine?
Answer: The pros:
1) The dialysis machine takes over the work of the kidney, preventing the build-up of toxic metabolites.  Kidney failure is a spectrum of disease - there are acute causes (that may be reversible) and chronic causes (with slow decrease in kidney function).  In the worse case senario with complete lack of function, death would occur in a week. 
2) Dialysis can act as a bridge - to a kidney transplant if the damage is permanent, or until the body can heal itself and resume normal kidney function if the damage is not permanent.  
3) Dialysis also allows a means to take off extra body water.  Urination is the main way the body gets rid of excess water - if the kidneys are not working properly, you may or may not be able to produce any urine.  Extra water causes diffuse swelling in the body tissues, including the lungs (which may cause trouble breathing). 

The cons:
1) Time.  Dialysis is done three times a week, usually for 3 hours.  For some people this may be done more frequently, especially if the nephrologist is trying to take off fluids.
2) Risk of infection.  In order to do dialysis, a very large catheter is needed to allow sufficient blood flow.  If known in advance, a fistula is placed into the arm, and a needle is inserted into it each time (A fistula is surgically created by connecting a large artery in the arm to a large vein - this gives a high flow system).  Otherwise, a catheter is placed into the jugular vein or the femoral vein.   These are prone to become infected - either in the skin around it, or by allowing introduction of bacteria into the blood stream.
3).  Medication changes.  Most medications have a known time that they are active in the body.  With renal failure, this is usually slowed down, but still occurs at a constant rate over time.  When dialysis starts, there is no longer a predictable amount of medication in your system.  Physicians have gotten pretty good at working around this, but it still can be an issue.
4).  Hypotension (low blood pressure).  With kidney disease, it is very important to keep the blood pressure low - this prevents further damage to the kidney (most people on dialysis have some residual kidney function - just not enough to be sufficient).  However, while dialysis is being done, there are large changes in the amount of blood/fluid in circulation in the body.  This can cause abrupt lowering of blood pressure.   

If the kidney damage is reversible - and the patient could eventually come off of dialysis, the pros definately outweigh the cons.   If the kidney damage is permanent, and the patient is not a candidate for transplant, this has to be a very individualized answer - depending on their values and quality of life, the scale could tip in either direction........

Title: PHYSICS multiple choice.  the moment of inertia of an object:?
Question: a. is a vector
b. depends on the choice of rotation axis.
c. is maximal around an axis passing through the center of the object
d. is an inherent property of the object, like mass
Answer: First of all, MoI is NOT a vector, so A is false.  Angular momentum is a vector, so MoI*V is a vector.

B is true in that the MoI of an object is the sum of the individual pieces of mass times their distance from the center of rotation squared.  I have a small MoI relative to the chair I'm sitting in and can change my angular velocity fairly easily.  My MoI relative to the center of the earth is huge and it would take lots of energy to get me to change my angular velocity relative to the earth.

C is false based on what I said in B.  There further you are from the axis of rotation, the larger the MoI.

D is true as long as you say 'for any given radius' or 'for any given axis of rotation', then the MoI is a property of the shape and density of the object.

3. Type in MSConfig

Title: Bipolar or just anxiety disorder?
Question: How do I tell the difference? Iam currently on anti depressants and I feel as though I may be bipolar.
Answer: Talk to you psychiatrist.  The most notable clinical feature of bipolar disorder is dramatic mood swings.  As compared to an anxiety disorder or depression where your moods will may be impacted by external factors, but will otherwise remain relatively level, in bipolar disorder patients cycle through periods of mania and depression.  But you should really really talk to your psychiatrist - I assure you he or she knows a lot more about it that I do.  Also, antidepressents effect your mood (obviously - that's the whole point), and may be responsible for some or all of you symptoms.  Your doctor may want to try a different anti-depressent or take you off them entirely for a while before deciding on a new diagnosis.\n\nPS. Anti-depressants are a standard treatment for anxiety disorders.

Question: How and where is limestone formed?
Answer: Limestone Formation 101:

1.) Ocean organisms that contain calcium carbonate in their shells (shellfish or forams)die & settle to the bottom of the ocean floor.
2.) At certain depths within the ocean, calcium carbonate begins to dissolve.
3.)Deposits build up over time (millions of years)
4.)Oceans transgress & regress (move inland & back out again) placing layer upon layer down over time.
5.)All the layering & pressure from the ocean above causes the dissolved CaCO3 to harden into rock.
6.)Sometimes pieces of shells are included in the rock (fossiliferous limestone - containing fossils)
7.)Poof...There you have the recipe for limestone.

Question: how does bile aid in the digestion and absorption of fats?
Answer: Bile, bitter, neutral, or slightly alkaline fluid secreted by the liver and passed through a duct into the gallbladder, where it is stored and, as necessary, released into the duodenum. As formed in the liver, bile is a thin, watery fluid to which the gallbladder adds a mucous secretion, forming a complex thickened and stringy substance consisting of salts and bile salts, proteins, cholesterol, hormones, and enzymes. The gallbladder returns water containing salts and other materials to the circulation and concentrates the complex further by a tenfold reduction of the bile salts, which the liver synthesizes from cholesterol. Such foods as fats, egg yolk, and foods rich in cholesterol cause concentrated bile, together with secretions from the pancreas, to be discharged into the duodenum to promote digestion, to stimulate peristalsis and absorption, and to carry off excess cholesterol and the disintegration products of overage red blood cells. The hemoglobin of such disintegrating cells degrades rapidly into reddish-yellow bilirubin, predominant in the bile of carnivorous and omnivorous animals, and biliverdin, a green pigment that appears in the bile of herbivores. Under normal conditions, the liver efficiently clears these pigments.\n\nCertain conditions create an inability to excrete bile, and this may create serious disabilities, such as jaundice. In obese and immobilized persons, in pregnant women, and in cases of obstruction of flow of bile, gallstones may be formed by precipitation of bilirubin in combination with calcium and cholesterol. Stasis frequently coexists with inflammation and infection of the gallbladder; this may alter the concentration of bile constituents and create debris around which bile and its components may precipitate to form gallstones, which may then block the common bile duct to reduce or stop the flow of bile. Inflammation and infection, together with the consequent regurgitation of bile into the liver, may damage that organ, sometimes causing cirrhosis.\n\n© 1993-2003 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Title: why is the sky blue?
Question: it's the age old question....
Answer: The sky appears blue because the gases(mainly nitrogen and oxygen) present in our atmosphere vibrate at a specific frequency.  From the light that we can see, ie.. blue, green, red, yellow...etc, the the higher frequency colors are absorbed more by the atmosphere than the lower frequency(actually they're scattered, they still make it to us but indirectly whereas the yellowish color of the sun is more direct).  So blue, green, and violet(violet having the shortest wavelength) are absorbed by the atmosphere, while red, yellow and orange are allowed through.   The color of blue that we perceive the sky varies from day to day based on the content of gases present and the frequency that they vibrate.  It works the same way as light passing through a blue balloon, except in this case the balloon is our atmosphere.

A more holistic approach has been favored by institutions such as the United Nations Development Program, which annually measures the Human Development Index (HDI) for a wide number of nations; the HDI is composed of three variables:\n\n1. GDP per capita, adjusted by PPP\n2. Life expectancy at birth\n3. Literacy proportion\n\nFor more info on GDP calculations and PPP, look them up in a macroeconomics textbook: Dornbusch, Fisher and Startz or Mankiw are good options.

Question: Asian Archipelago?
Answer: Southeast Asia is geographically divided into two regions, namely Indochina and the Malay Archipelago.

Indochina or sometimes mainland Southeast Asia includes all of:

 
Topography of Southeast Asia 
Relief Map of SE Asia on the globe at the Field Museum, Chicago, Illinois, United States 
Mount KinabaluMyanmar 
Cambodia 
Lao PDR 
Thailand 
Vietnam 
The Malay archipelago (Malay: Nusantara), variously Malay World, an ethno-cultural notion, or maritime Southeast Asia consists of:

Brunei 
East Timor 
Indonesia 
Philippines 
Malaysia 
Singapore 
Malaysia is divided by the South China Sea. Peninsular Malaysia is on the mainland while East Malaysia is on Borneo, the largest islands in the region. However, Malaysia is often considered an archipelagic nation.

Geologically the Malay archipelago is very interesting, being one of the most active vulcanological regions in the world. Geological uplifts in the region have also produced some impressive mountains, culminating in Mount Kinabalu in Sabah, Malaysia on the island of Borneo with a height of 4,101 metres (13,455 ft) and also Puncak Jaya in Irian Jaya, Indonesia at 4,884 metres (16,024 ft), on the island of New Guinea.

There are various conflicting territorial and/or maritime claims, both among these countries and even involving other parties (notably both Chinas in the case of the Spratly Islands).

Contrary to common misconception, most of the inhabitants of archipelagic Southeast Asia are not Pacific Islanders. However, it is worth noting that the eastern parts of Indonesia and Timor-Leste (east of Wallace line) are geographically parts of Oceania.

[edit]
Population
Southeast Asia has an area of approx. 4,000,000 km² (1.6 million sq miles). As of 2004, more than 593 million people lived in the region, far over a sixth of them (+114 million) on the Indonesian island of Java, the most densely populated island in the world. The distribution of the religions and people is diverse in Southeast Asia and varies by country. And about 30 million Overseas Chinese are living here, most prominently Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand. see Chinatowns

[edit]
Ethnic groups in the subregion
Southeast Asians are primarily of Asiatic stock. According to a recent Stanford genetic study, the Southeast Asian population is entirely far from being homogeneous. Although primarily descendants of Austronesian, Tai, and Mon-Khmer-speaking immigrants who migrated from Southern China during the Iron Age, there are overlays of Chinese, European, as well as Papuan genes. The Philippines, Malaysia, and Singapore have substantial Eurasian populations.

Brunei: Malay (69%), Chinese (18%), Indigenous Bruneians (6%), Others (7%) 
Cambodia: Khmer (94%), Chinese (4%), Vietnamese (1%), Others (mostly Chams) (1%) 
East Timor: Tetun (10%), Mambae (8%), Makasae (8%), Tukudede (6%), Bunak (5%), Galoli (5%), Kemak (5%), Fataluku (3%), Baikeno (2%), Others (48%) 
Indonesia: Javanese (45%), Sundanese (14%), Madurese (8%), Chinese (2%), Others (31%) 
Laos: Lowland Lao (56%), Lao Theung (34%), Lao Soung (10%) 
Malaysia: Malay and Orang Asli (60%), Chinese (25%), South Asian (10%), Others (3%) 
Myanmar: Bamar (68%), Shan (9%), Karen (6%), Rakhine (4%), Others (includes Chinese and South Asians) (13%) 
Philippines: Filipino (80%), Chinese (7%), South Asian (5%), Europeans and Americans (4%), Arab (3%), Others (1%) 
Singapore: Chinese (76%), Malay (15%), South Asian (7%), Others (2%) 
Thailand: Thai (75%), Chinese (14%), Malay (4%), Khmer (3%), Others (4%) 
Vietnam: Vietnamese (88%), Chinese (4%), Thai (2%), Others (6%) 
[edit]
Religions in the subregion
Countries in Southeast Asia practise many different religions. Mainland SEA countries, that is, Thailand, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar, practise predominantly Buddhism. Title: IP address help?
Question: Okay so I bought a new computer to put in my room. I have cable internet at my house and i want to get internet acesss on both computers without buying a new line or ip addres from my provider. I bought a switch in hopes that it would be my quick fix. Have my modem connected to the switch, and my two computers connect to the switch. I tried it and only one computer gets internet. What do I do? is it something to do with my IP address? How do i fix it?
Answer: You should have bought a router instead of a switch, the router does network address translation so that both computers can use the internet connection. However not all is lost. You can get away with some software solution. Question: What really distinguishes AJAX programming from traditional web programming (html/javascript)?
Answer: AJAX uses a bit of javascript that uses the XmlHTTP object.  This object, opens up a connection to a Web server, transmits and receives data, then calls back the javascript on the page which was used to invoke it.\n\nWhat this means is that changes on the client side can communicate with the server, then dynamically update the client user interface without having to request a new Web page from the server.\n\nWhile this slightly complicates developing Web applications that use AJAX technologies (which, by the way, is just a name given to the various technologies employed to use this methodology), it makes for a very smooth user experience since they are not constantly refreshing Web pages.\n\nAJAX applications give an appearance of a 'thick client' application while still being a 'thin client' (i.e. application that runs in a Web browser.)  However, it is important to note that network communication is still going on in the background while the application is being used.

Question: I have a number 2 lead pencil, was there ever a number 1 or 3?
Answer: Yes.  They represent different grades of pencil.  I do a lot of pencil sketching and use many grades of pencil depending on the need and effect I'm looking for.

It's been my experience that the softer grades are great for contrast and shading. They're also good for darkening large areas of a drawing.  They do tend to "cake up" and smudge easily if too much is applied.

The harder grades are great for fine lines and when exact detailing is required.  They can hold a razor sharp point longer too.  Harder grades are okay for light shading but not very good when there's a need for a lot of high contrast darkening.

The following link shows a visual grading scale for reference.

Question: What type of fruit did eve eat?
Answer: The Book of Enoch 31:4, purporting to be written by the antediluvian prophet Enoch, describes the tree of knowledge as follows:

"It was like a species of the tamarind tree, bearing fruit which resembled grapes extremely fine; and its fragrance extended to a considerable distance. I exclaimed, How beautiful is this tree, and how delightful is its appearance!" 
In western art, the fruit is most commonly depicted as an apple. One possible reason for this arises from a medieval pun. It was a source of humor to monks that the Latin term for evil (malus) was similar to the word of apple (malum). Thus it was often said that by eating the malum (apple), Eve contracted malus (evil). There is, however, no textual or historical evidence by which to argue the literalness of this image.

Jewish thought contains additional options. Rabbi Meir says: "The fruit of (the Tree of Knowledge of Good-and-Evil) was a grape..."; Rabbi Nechemia says: "It was a fig..."; Rabbi Yehuda says: "It was wheat..." Talmud, Brachot 40a

The reason it is sometimes surmised to have been a fig is that they used fig leaves to cover themself after eating it, either because the leaves were nearby, or because God creates the cure before the illness, and the same tree that caused the problem is also used to remedy it. Another explanation lies within the "fruit" of the fig tree, the fig itself, which is not actually a fruit but rather a flower of sorts, serving as the tree's genitalia. It is said that when they bit into the fig, they saw that what appeared to be a fruit on the outside had concealed the reproductive organs within itself. Adam and Eve then looked at each other and felt ashamed that their reproductive organs were simply exposed, and covered them with the large leaves from the same tree. Some commentators hold that it might have been a grape, and that Eve actually made, and drank, wine.

Ethno-botanists have proposed the iboga plant (Tabernanthe iboga) as the Tree of Knowledge. The ground up bark contains a dissociative substance, ibogaine, which has been traditionally used in Bwiti religious ceremony in Central Africa. Other hallucinogens, in particular the Fly agaric mushroom, have also been proposed as the Tree.

Christian sects like the Coptics of Jamaica, and other peoples of faith, especially the Rastafarians believe it to be the Marijuana plant.

Even network operating systems that have their own protocols, such as Netware, also support TCP/IP.

Question: Who is Dale Carnegie?
Answer: Who was Dale Carnegie?
The following is excerpted from the 1983 World Book Encylopedia 
CARNEGIE, DALE (1888-1955), was a pioneer in public speaking and personality development. He became famous by showing others how to become successful. His book How to Win Friends and Influence People (1936) has sold more than 10 million copies and has been translated into many languages. His books became popular because of his illustrative stories and simple, well-phrased rules. Two of his most famous maxims are, "Believe that you will succeed, and you will," and "Learn to love, respect and enjoy other people." His other books include How to Stop Worrying and Start Living (1948). Toward the beginning of his career, Carnegie wrote Public Speaking and Influencing Men in Business (1931), which became a standard text.

Carnegie attended Warrensburg (Mo.) State Teachers College, and became a salesman for Armour and Company. Later, he taught public speaking to businessmen. He was born in Mary ville, Mo.


--Carl Niemeyer

Question: What can you tell me about thermal insulation?
Answer: Thermal insulation blocks the movement of heat.

Typical thermal insulations are spun glass or fiber glass that traps air.  Trapped dead air is a very good insulator because it prevents convection transfer of heat.

A vacuum is also a good insulator and that is how a thermos bottle works.

Styrafoam is another excellent insulator.

The higher the R value on an insulating product, the more heat that it will block.

Consider this temperature gradient and heat flow:

Outside it is 5ºF.  Inside it is 70ºF.  Over the span of 4 to 6" in a normal wall, the temp gradient is 65 degrees!  What prevents all that heat from rushing outside?  Good insulation of R13-R19 in the wall.

Title: disposable camera?
Question: how it works, material used
Answer: The dictionary calls a "camera" a chamber and when the court meet "in camera" it is in the judge's chamber (away from the public and jury).  Therefore a photographer's camera is nothing more than a darkened chamber that protects film from light exposure until you click and open an aperture to let the light (and view) in through the focusing lens just long enough to expose the film.  Usually you can wind the film to obtain a series of exposures on a roll of film.  The most expensive cameras often take only one picture but with remarkable clarity because of the very costly lenses and timing mechanisms.  These might be used to shoot the gatefold in color for a men's magazine, etc.  A disposable camera performs the same function for snapshots using barely adequate but inexpensive lenses with little control of the camera and photo possible.  Because it is mass-produced and not designed to be refilled with fresh film, it is cheap enough to use once and throw away (as in disposable).

Silent Soil From Silent Days


His song is being written by his ways;
for each, but once, may don life’s wings and fly.
One man controls the volume of his days.

A breast so warm, a collar blue, may raise
him to his feet—but soon will wave thereby,
his song is being written by his ways.

His peers and he conquer the world, a phase
where sight becomes so bright, it blinds the eye.
This man controls the volume of his days.

The vice of life so twists as youth betrays—
his well of youth, so opportune, near dry.
His song is being written by his ways.

With desperate fire, his gray will sets to blaze:
too weak, too late, too dry to catch the eye,
this man controlled the volume of his days.

And now, in silent soil from silent days,
cry fools that thought no scythe would make them lie.
Each song is being written by his ways,
One man controls the volume of his days.

Question: If my mom has diabetes 2 am i at risk to?
Answer: Whoa... I can see there is a lot of misunderstanding about diabetes.  The thing you need to know is that there are two types of diabetes.

Type 1 Diabetes presents more commonly during early childhood or early puberty but can occur at any age.  Type 1 specifically refers to diabetes resulting from the destruction of insulin-secreting cells in your pancreas.  All Type 1 diabetics require insulin because their body no longer makes it.

Type 2 Diabetes presents more commonly in adulthood but can occur at any age and is being seen in younger and younger patients.  Type 2 specifically refers to diabetes resulting from your body's becoming more resistant (or less sensitive) to the insulin that your pancreas produces.  Most patients can be treated with oral medications that improve your body's sensitivity to your endogenous insulin or stimulate more insulin release from your pancreas.  Type 2 diabetics have high levels of insulin circulating unlike Type 1 diabetics.  Some Type 2 diabetics may go on to need insulin if their oral medications are not adequately controlling their sugars; most will be on a combination of insulin and oral meds.

Both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes are multifactorial.  There are both genetic and environmental factors that lead to the disease.  Therefore, just because one identical twin has diabetes (either kind) does not necessarily mean that the other will get it as well!

Population studies have shown that for Type 1 diabetes...
If your mom has Type 1 DM - your risk is 1 in 17
If your mom has Type 1 DM and had you before age 25 - your risk 1 in 25
If your mom has Type 1 DM and had you after age 25 - your risk 1 in 100
If your mom got Type 1 DM before she was 11 - the above risk doubles
If both your parents have Type 1 DM - your risk is 1 in 5

For Type 2 diabetes...
If you have one parent who had Type 2 DM before 50 - your risk is 1 in 7
If you have one parent who had Type 2 DM after 50 - your risk is 1 in 13
If you have two parents with Type 2 DM - your risk is 1 in 2
If you have an identical twin with Type 2 DM - your risk is 3 in 4

This information is all available from the American Diabetes Association.  As you can see, Type 2 diabetes actually has a higher inherited risk than Type 1!  There are things that you can do to minimize your chances of developing Type 2 DM, though, even though you are at risk.  That includes regular exercise, maintenance of a healthy weight, and reducing fat and calorie intake.  There are also some medications that can reduce your risk of developing Type 2 DM; you should talk to your doctor about whether these would be appropriate for you.  Above all, don't worry!  You are expressing concern about your health which is the FIRST STEP!  If you are motivated to take the appropriate steps towards maintaining your health, the odds of preventing diabetes are in your favor!!  Good luck!

EDIT:
To justwannaknow - I think what you say is misleading.  The AMA's recommendation in 2002 was for people to take a daily multivitamin.  There is still no recommendation for physicians to advise patients to take herbal supplements and other nutritional supplements like "Glycoscience".

To hmt42play - Islet cell transplants are not being recommended for patients with Type 2 diabetes!!!  As you diabetes educator, you should be aware of this!  Type 2 diabetics generally have functioning islet cells and DO produce insulin.  The problem is with insulin resistance so giving them more islet cells would not resolve the underlying problem.  Islet cell transplants are currently only being used in unstable Type 1 diabetics.  Please do not give this poor woman the idea that islet cell transplantation is a cure for Type 2 diabetes!

Question: want to know more about 47xxy?
Answer: There are 23 pairs of chromosomes found in each cell of the body, and each contain genes that determine our coloring, our features, and our sex. Women inherit two X chromosomes -- one from each parent, written 46,XX.  Men inherit an X chromosome from their mothers and a Y chromosome from their fathers, written 46,XY.  Some individuals, however, have an additional X chromosome in their chromosomal arrangement, referred to as 47,XXY, or more commonly, just XXY.  The cause is unknown, yet XXY occurs in approximately 1 in every 500 to 1000 live male births, making it one of the most common chromosome variations.   The XXY variation is identified in an individual through a karyotype, a buccal smear, or FISH.

Question: What Is Correlation and Cross Correlation?
Answer: Correlation is determining the relationship of one variable to the values of other variables using collected data.\n\nFor example if you considered a person's salary, you might find it correlates with: number of years of education, and number of years of employment, along with other variables.\n\nCross-correlation means a correlation just between 2 variables. You get that expression, because you can evaluate if two variables cross correlate, by plotting one variable on the X and one on the Y axis of a graph. If the cloud of points that result are clustered around a straight line then they cross correlate well.

Title: How is  a Magnet made?
Question: Those big MRI machines made me wonder about the construction method of a magnet.
Answer: There are some natural magnets. For example, the mineral magnetite is magnetic, and is found in lodestones. \n\nIf you have a magnet, you can stroke a piece of metal (not all metals, but some) and magnetize it; that is, turn it into a magnet. You line up the magnetic domains when you stroke it so it has a net magnetic field. If you put a radio reciever nearby tuned to the right frequency, you can hear the domains flip as you do this; this is called the Barkhausen effect. \n\nThere are also electromagnets. Passing an electric current through a coiled wire wrapped around the right kind of metal (called a shunt) produces a magnet. This is the kind of magnet one finds in MRI machines.

Question: How do we have the ability to blur our vision? What happens in the eye when we do that?
Answer: there are little muscles above and below the lens of the eye, which, in profile, is shaped like an oval or elipse.  When those muscles are relaxed or flexed, the oval is either stretched or becomes shorter, changing the shape of the lens, thus manipulating lightrays (reflecting off of the thing we are "seeing") traveling through the lens, so that these rays (depending on the distance you are from what you're looking at and what you're doing with those muscles) are more focused or less focused in the retina.  If the light rays aren't focused correctly back there, then you've got a blurry image.  At least, that's what I THINK is going on if I remember correctly from a class I took last year....  So, in short, it's our ability to manipulate our eyes' lenses with those little muscles that makes us able to blur (or focus) our vision... good luck.

Title: Has anyone ever heard or Emetophobia?
Question: Do you know any sufferers?
Answer: Emetophobia is an excessive or irrational fear of vomiting or of being around others who are vomiting. It is one of the most common specific phobias. In survey research, six percent of the U.S. population claims to fear being sick, although a much smaller number suffer from actual emetophobia, which manifests itself through a variety of phobic behavior.\n\nNearly every emetophobic contracted their phobia as a result of a traumatic incident of vomiting that happened to them between the ages of six and ten. Most emetophobics claim they can will themselves to avoid vomiting, sometimes resulting in Irritable Bowel Syndrome, and other illness. A survey of an Internet group of emetophobics found that the average member had last vomited at least twelve years earlier. On average, it is suggested that most emetophobics have been sick five or fewer times in their lives.\n\nEmetophobics are known to go to great lengths to avoid people who may be sick, to avoid being in public places where people may do so, and above all, to practice eating habits in such a manner as to minimize the chance of their heaving - many emetophobics lead strict diet regimes and often avoid foods that are known to produce the most liekly chance of food poisoning - meat and dairy products for example. Most emetophobics have very specific diets, and avoid not only food that once caused them to vomit, but also anything they suspect of being a possible cause of such illness.\n\nAnxiety concerning vomiting, or being in close proximity to anyone that might vomit can cause irrational behaviour, and often induce panic attacks. Emetophobia can have a very difficult and stressful influence on everyday life, the very nature of the illness being ever present. Many emetophobics would rather face illness than face the fear of vomiting, and in almost every case, an emetophobics body would respond to this irrational fear. Most emetophobics fear vomiting themselves, but in some cases, it has been claimed that fear of seeing other people vomit can induce an even greater phobic response than if they were to be sick themselves/\n\nEmetophobia is treated in the way common to most specific phobias.

Question: How to calculate circuit breaker rating?
Answer: Add the loads in amperes of each of the appliances on that circuit.  Make sure that the total is less than the ampere rating of the circuit breaker.  You should probably only use about 3/4 of the amperes the circuit breaker is rated for.  For example, a 20 Amp breaker should only be loaded with about 15 Amps.\n\nIf only the wattage of an appliance is given, divide the wattage by the voltage to obtain the amperes.  For example, a toaster may draw 1200 watts.  1200 watts / 120 V = 10 Amps.  A light bulb may draw 60 watts.  60 watts / 120 V = .5 Amps.

Title: physics question?
Question: An object has a mass of 27 kg. The acceleration of gravity is 9.8 m/s^2. What is its weight on the earth? Answer in units of N.
Answer: Multiply the two numbers and you are done.

See weight is equal to force.

Force is the rate of change of momentum but since the mass doesn't change the force is then equal to mass times acceleration or F = ma

m, is mass in kg
a is acceleration of gravity in m/s^2

and the units of N, Newtons, is kg-m/s^2

So your answer is 27 * 9.8 N

Title: What type of growth or decay function does one encounter in work or in personal life?
Question: This is in regards to exponential and logarithmic applications in mathematics.  I need some examples of either so I can better understand the concepts in real-life or real-world scenarios.
Answer: 1.  The von Bertalanffy growth function (VBGF) introduced by von Bertalanffy in 1938 predicts the length of a shark as a function of its age, L = L(t): L(t) = Loo - (Loo - Lo) exp(-kt) 
2.  Examples of exponential growth
Biology. 
Microorganisms in a culture dish will grow exponentially, at first, after the first microorganism appears (but then logistically until the available food is exhausted, when growth stops). 
A virus (SARS, West Nile, smallpox) of sufficient infectivity (k > 0) will spread exponentially at first, if no artificial immunization is available. Each infected person can infect multiple new people. 
Human population, if the number of births and deaths per person per year were to remain constant (but also see logistic growth). 
Many responses of living beings to stimuli, including human perception, are logarithmic responses, which are the inverse of exponential responses; the loudness and frequency of sound are perceived logarithmically, even with very faint stimulus, within the limits of perception. This is the reason that exponentially increasing the brightness of visual stimuli is perceived by humans as a smooth (linear) increase, rather than an exponential increase. This has survival value. Generally it is important for the organisms to respond to stimuli in a wide range of levels, from very low levels, to very high levels, while the accuracy of the estimation of differences at high levels of stimulus is much less important for survival. 
Electroengineering 
Charging and discharging of capacitors and changes in current in inductors are also exponential growth and decay phenomena. Engineers use a rule of five time constants to estimate when a steady state has been reached. 
Computer technology 
Processing power of computers. See also Moore's law and technological singularity (under exponential growth, there are no such singularities). 
Internet traffic growth. 
Wikipedia:Modelling Wikipedia's growth - an analysis of Wikipedia's growth rates based on article growth rates and other statistics 
Investment. The effect of compound interest over many years has a substantial effect on savings and a person's ability to retire. See also rule of 72 
Physics 
Atmospheric pressure decreases exponentially with increasing height above sea level, at a rate of about 12% per 1000m. 
Nuclear chain reaction (the concept behind nuclear weapons). Each uranium nucleus that undergoes fission produces multiple neutrons, each of which can be absorbed by adjacent uranium atoms, causing them to fission in turn. If the probability of neutron absorption exceeds the probability of neutron escape (a function of the shape and mass of the uranium), k > 0 and so the production rate of neutrons and induced uranium fissions increases exponentially, in an uncontrolled reaction. 
Newton's law of cooling  where T is temperature, t is time, and, A, D, and k > 0 are constants, is an example of exponential decay. 
Multi-level marketing 
Exponential increases appear in each level of a starting member's downline as each subsequent member recruits more people.

Question: How can you speak using your diaphragm?
Answer: Diaphragm breathing is used, for example, in singing and playing the flute; because it enables you to take in more air, and it gives you more control over your breathing. People normally breathe in their chest. You can tell if you're using chest breathing because your shoulders rise and fall. With diaphragm breathing it is the stomach region that moves. Diaphragm breathing is a much deeper breathing than chest breathing. It is also quite difficult to achieve properly. 

To manage it, you have to take a slow, deep breath, remembering not to move your chest. Do it standing or lying down; you have to make a conscious effort to get the air into your stomach (this doesn't really happen, but it feels like it. The reason diaphragmatic breathing gets more air into you is that the diaphragm muscle stretches the lungs so that most of them fill up with air. It helps to have a hand on your stomach, or to have someone watching you and telling you that you're moving your shoulders. You can also lie down and put a pile of books on your stomach, so that you can see whenever they rise or fall. When you breathe out, try to keep your stomach (and the books) up, by keeping the diaphragm tense.

It's quite difficult, but practice makes perfect. :)

Title: What is bigger?
Question: what is bigger, the atom or the ion?

Question: How do wirlpools start in the ocean?
Answer: As the water starts to circle, it is thrown to the outside, due to centrifugal force (to be more accurate, the force that it experiences is centripetal force=(mv^2)/r since centrifugal force is a so-called fictitious force). As it's thrown outside, it starts to move faster (when things move in a circle, the things that are nearer the outside move faster than things near the center; you can see this if you have a "old-fashioned" record player by putting two coins on it, one near the center and one near the outer edge and trace how long it takes them to complete the lengths of their paths). So the circling water near the outer rim is moving very fast and experiences bigger forces (since the force is proportional to velocity). But the water near the middle is moving slower because it's being dragged along the bottom and so ends up slowing down much more. Since the water near the bottom is moving so slowly, it exhibits a much lower centrifugal force and so there is little to no centrifugal force near the bottom (or middle). This is why you have a whirlpool (vortex): the water near the top is pushed out more (since there's higher centrifugal force there) and the water near the bottom is hardly pushed outward at all (since there's lower centrifugal force near the bottom to push it out).

Answer: CRC errors mean that when the computer is checking the data transferred from the DVD drive with the data in RAM the answers are different.  This means that the data transfer is corrupting somehow on your mother computer.  There may be a problem with the device driver for your DVD or the DVD may be defective. Question: Everything i think of is operant conditioning, in terms of parenting.I cant for the life of me think of any cl
Answer: The importance of empathy for moral socialisation was one of the reason for the development of the violence inhibition mechanism model of psychopathy.34 43 44 This model was also prompted by work suggesting that most social animals possess mechanisms for the control of aggression.45 46 They noted that submission cues displayed to a conspecific aggressor terminate attacksfor example, an aggressor dog will cease fighting if its opponent bares its throat. The violence inhibition mechanism (VIM) is considered to be a functionally similar mechanism in humans where sad facial affects (distress cues) function as a human submission response. At its simplest, the VIM is thought to be a system that when activated by distress cues, the sad and fearful expressions of others, results in increased autonomic activity, attention and activation of the brain stem threat response system (usually resulting in freezing).43 According to the model, moral socialisation occurs through the pairing of the activation of the mechanism by distress cues with representations of the acts which caused the distress cues (moral transgressionsfor example, one person hitting another).43 A process of classical conditioning results in these representations of moral transgressions becoming triggers for the mechanism. The appropriately developing child thus initially finds the pain of others' aversive and then, through socialisation, thoughts of acts that cause pain to others aversive also. \n\nBlair has proposed that psychopathic persons have had disruption to this system such that representations of acts that cause harm to others do not become triggers for the VIM.43 This is thought to occur because the signal to the learning system concerning emotionally aversive stimuli is mutedthat is, the unconditioned stimulus (US) signal is diminished, thus impairing the formation of US-conditioned stimulus (CS) associations. Certainly, the autonomic response of psychopathic persons to the aversive US of sad and fearful facial expressions is muted relative to controls.34 At the neural level, this has been attributed to dysfunction within the amygdala.23 47

Question: are isotopes of the same element indistinguishable?
Answer: Isotopes of the same element have *almost* identical chemical properties. They can be distinguished because they have different masses (from a different number of neutrons in the nucleus). But this effect is usually very small. One exception is hydrogen. The isotope consisting of one protoon and one neutron in the nucleus (deuterium) has double the mass of a regular hydrogen atom, and this can have observable effects even on the chemistry.

Question: Why use a static IP address rather than a Dynamic?
Answer: In a corporate network, you want a Static IP for any servers or any computers hosting resources or providing any kind of service (web servers, printers, routers, file servers, etc). That's because a Dynamic IP does not guarantee a machine will keep the same IP all the time, and if a server/service provider changes IP, the clients may not be able to find it.  \n\nIt's the same for the Internet--- if people/web clients/whatever external computer will be coming to your computer to retrieve information or services, it has to be able to find the resource.  \n\nThis is usually facilitated by DNS which keeps track of server/service names and their corresponding IP's; DNS updates to client machines is sometimes slow, so the clients may go looking in the old location (old IP) if the server changes IP, and the DNS updates themselves may be done manually so the DNS server may not even be aware that your server has changed IP.

Title: If water is so good for you then why does it RUST pipes???
Question: and other things?
Like Metal and such?? WHY???
Answer: Rust is the substance formed when iron compounds corrode in the presence of oxygen and water. It is a mixture of iron oxides and hydroxides. Rusting is a common term for corrosion, and usually corrosion of steel.

Iron is found naturally in the ore haematite as iron oxide, and metallic iron tends to return to a similar state when exposed to air, (hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, etc.) and water. This corrosion is due to the oxidation reaction when iron metal returns to an energetically favourable state. Energy is given off when rust forms. The process of rusting can be summarized as three basic stages: The formation of iron(II) ions from the metal; the formation of hydroxide ions; and their reaction together, with the addition of oxygen, to create rust.

Iron is the main component of steel and the corrosion of steel is observed more frequently, since iron is rarely used without alloying in the present day.

When steel contacts water, an electrochemical process starts. On the surface of the metal, iron is oxidized to iron(II):

    Fe → Fe2+ + 2e−

The electrons released travel to the edges of the water droplet, where there is plenty of dissolved oxygen. They reduce the oxygen and water to hydroxide ions:

    4e− + O2 + 2H2O → 4OH−

The hydroxide ions react with the iron(II) ions and more dissolved oxygen to form iron oxide. The hydration is variable, however in its most general form:

    Fe2+ + 2OH− → Fe(OH)2
    4Fe(OH)2 + O2 → 2(Fe2O3.xH2O) + 2H2O

Hence, rust is hydrated iron(III) oxide. Corrosion tends to progress faster in seawater than fresh water due to higher concentration of sodium chloride ions, making the solution more conductive. Rusting is also accelerated in the presence of acids, but inhibited by alkalis. Rust can often be removed through electrolysis, however the base metal object can not be restored through this method.

Title: pathway of taste perception?
Question: Kindly answer this bcus i need it 2morrow....\nIt's all about the Taste Organ..
Answer: The sense of taste of course begins with the taste buds located primarily on the tongue, but also on the soft palate, cheeks, pharynx, and epiglottis.  Chemicals in food stimulate sensory neurons in the taste buds, which communicate with the brain via one of three cranial nerves: the facial nerve (VII), the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), or the vagus nerve (X).  These nerves enter the central nervous system at the level of the brainstem, synapsing with secondary neurons in the solitary nucleus.  The signals then pass upwards through the thalamus to the gustatory cortex, which is part of the primary somatosensory cortex located on the surface of the parietal lobes.  Note that the functioning of this pathway depends heavily on normal functioning of the sense of smell.  This is why your food tastes bland when you have a bad cold with a stuffy nose.
